title: Beautiful, disturbing, highly visual.
review: Requiem is a beautiful movie that you will have to dislike to appreciate. Highly confrontational, Darren Aronofsky's masterpiece brings the drug 'epidemic' to a level that Steven Soderbergh's 'Traffic' could not reach. This film is both visually and aurally appealing; Darren Aronofsky's direction and Clint Mansell's score provide a sympathetic realism that is much more frightening than any horror movie. Overall, Requiem For A Dream is cast , directed, acted, shot and written brilliantly, but I would be hesitant to recommend it to anyone with a weak stomach.  Darren Aronofsky is definitely a director to look out for, and it is highly possible that he rescues the somewhat dull Batman franchise.

title: Visually hyperactive, wonderful
review: Being one of the legion of fans of Lock Stock & Two Smoking Barrels, I obviously had quite an expectation for Guy Ritchie's second film, Snatch. Having read reviews for Snatch prior to seeing it, I expected to see Lock Stock version two.  However, I was very pleasantly surprised to see that this was not the case. Snatch is a brilliant standalone film that is visually amazing from start to finish.  Sometimes the case is with visually spectacular films that the characters/story lines aren't developed properly, but Guy Ritchie is just as good at dialogue as he is a director.  In a way Snatch improves on Lock Stock's only flaw - the acting.  Lock Stock was restrained financially, so they were forced to use second-rate actors with very little to no experience.  Snatch applies the familiarity and experience of actors such as Brad Pitt, Oscar winner Benicio Del Toro and Dennis Farina. Snatch is a visual and aural feast (Ritchie loves fast-paced music to match the action), and is well worth your while to view it. Snatch: 9/10
